awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Multi-omic characterization of the coral mucus during sedimentation disturbances
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. This research specifically looks at the watersheds of Hilo, Hawai'i and the role these have on coral survival in the bay. It is known that corals are affected by land runoff after heavy rains, but very little research has been done to investigate the mechanisms behind coral death. Coral survival depends greatly on the bacteria and molecules found in their surface mucus. The fellow will investigate how coral mucus changes in response to heavy rainfall. This project is important for demonstrating the interdependent relationship between land and ocean ecosystems. This project will broaden participation in biology by targeting Native Hawaiian youth. Native Hawaiians are one of the most underrepresented demographics in biology despite belonging to a culture that is rooted in scientific observation. 

The fellow will test the hypothesis that stable microbial and molecular communities will be temporarily disrupted during heavy rain events. Mucus collected from the most abundant coral species will be monitored over three heavy rain events. The microbiome and metabolome of coral mucus will be profiled and processed using next generation DNA sequencing and mass spectrometry techniques. Additionally, the fellow will expand research training in microbiome and metabolomic analysis while developing new methods in 3D underwater photogrammetry. The fellow will present the findings of this research throughout the duration of the project at the University of Hawai'i at Hilo's Keaholoa student center. The findings will also be shared throughout the local high schools in Hilo. A final community day at Honoli'i Beach Park will promote the importance of ocean stewardship across watersheds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
My journey into the world of coral reefs has been truly remarkable. Motivated by a simple yet profound question?how do corals withstand the challenges of heavy rain and sedimentation??my mission was to uncover the intricate interplay between corals and the microscopic world within their mucus, with a focus on their remarkable resilience. Guided by three core goals, I aimed to unravel the microbial dynamics within coral mucus during rain events, identify potential microbial threats during heavy rainfall, and craft immersive 3D models to visualize coral responses to sedimentation.


Even amidst the backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic, we reached significant milestones. By utilizing cutting-edge software, we meticulously recreated intricate 3D models of a coral-rich site in Hawaii, allowing us to virtually explore these captivating underwater realms. Our endeavor went beyond visualization: we mastered the art of measuring freshwater currents around reefs, a vital component in understanding coral responses to intense rain. Despite the research challenges posed by the pandemic, we formed unexpected partnerships with brands like Reef Footwear and Hydro Flask, effectively communicating the significance of coral research to an astonishing half a million people worldwide. This achievement is particularly remarkable considering the limitations of conducting in-person research during these unprecedented times.

Amidst the trials, our preliminary observations have been truly enlightening. As we embarked on the meticulous analysis of the microbial communities residing within coral mucus, we've begun unearthing insights that suggest how corals might navigate and endure environmental challenges. However, this is just the beginning. Much more study is needed to fully understand these intricate relationships.

This journey has also revealed challenges. Finding a non-invasive way to characterize coral microbiomes has proven to be quite intricate. Yet, this challenge holds the potential to reshape the landscape of coral research. If we can overcome this obstacle, it could revolutionize the way we study corals and their delicate ecosystems, opening new doors to understanding their resilience and vulnerabilities.

The reach of our project extends far beyond the scientific realm. It resonates deeply with the wider community, serving as a bridge between scientific exploration and public understanding. Our work engages through captivating podcasts, enlightening articles, and dynamic virtual platforms. Notably, our efforts resonate with the younger generation and those deeply rooted in Hawaiian heritage, reigniting a passion for science and nurturing a sense of stewardship for coral conservation. Moreover, our findings hold implications beyond scientific discussions. Our research bolsters our advocacy for policies that safeguard coral reefs from pollution and other threats, using our discoveries as a catalyst for positive change.

However, the narrative takes an exciting turn. The project's baton has been passed to a dedicated PhD student, a Native Hawaiian pursuing a degree in Environmental Science at Arizona State University. This student's profound connection to the study site, coupled with unwavering determination, has forged cross-institutional collaborations between ASU and the University of Hawaii at Hilo. Building on our foundation, they've enriched the project and are propelling it towards publication. This journey embodies more than just a project; it symbolizes the convergence of passion, dedication, and scientific pursuit, pushing boundaries and unlocking new frontiers in coral research.

Looking ahead, our aspirations remain ambitious. We're committed to unraveling the intricate mechanisms underpinning coral resilience, and our dedication to sharing discoveries persists unswayed. As we navigate research intricacies and the twists of life, our project stands as a testament to the remarkable synergy of scientific curiosity, determination, and innovation. This synergy generates waves of impact that resonate not only beneath the ocean's surface but also resonate deeply within people's lives.
